properties.Name: sixteenth century coin
properties.Description: In December 2013, a local man discovered a 16th-century coin while pursuing his hobby of metal detecting. The rare English shilling, minted between 1551 and 1553 during the brief reign of Edward VI, holds historical significance.

properties.Name: Arm Street Park Dock
properties.Description: Arm Street Park has been identified as a potential location in the report by the Collaborative to Improve Access to the Gorge. It enjoys strong support from the local community and current users of the Banfield Park dock. The popularity of the Banfield dock has sparked demand for increased public access to the Gorge waterway.

properties.Name: Emerson the elephant seal
properties.Description: Born in January 2022 at Bowman Bay in Deception Pass State Park within Puget Sound, Emerson the elephant seal has exhibited a tendency to molt in urban settings.

properties.Name: Japanese Gardens
properties.Description: From 1907 to 1942, the Esquimalt Japanese Tea Garden thrived as a bustling recreational center for people in Victoria.

properties.Name: Swim platform at Banfield Park
properties.Description: In mid-July 2022, Aryze Developments launched a floating public swim dock featuring a Japanese katsura tree, positioned near the Banfield public dock. in 2022, the City committed $300,000 to construct another swimming platform and install buoys to designate a protected swim zone. In 2024, further enhancements were established, such as a life-jacket loaner station, anchored buoys for a recreational swimming area, and additional swim steps to improve accessibility and safety.
properties.KeyWords: clean-up; public access; revitalization; swimming; watersports

properties.Name: Curtis Point
properties.Description: The Gorge Waterway was the focal point of swimming in Victoria, with notable attractions such as the towering 110-foot diving tower erected at Curtis Point in 1910. This iconic structure provided adventurous swimmers with a dramatic platform for diving until a tragic accident claimed the life of a diver in 1922. Following this incident, the diving tower was dismantled, signaling the conclusion of an era for aquatic recreation in the Gorge.

properties.Name: Craigflower Manor House National Historic Site
properties.Description: Established by the Hudson's Bay Company (HBC) in 1853, Craigflower Farm operated with indentured workers until 1865.  Then the property was changed from a farm to a country resort for four years, then being changed back into a farm until the 1930s. In 1923, the manor was repurposed as a recreational hall and leased for a charity camp for girls. In 1960, community members began to restore the manor, leading to its designation as a national historic site to preserve its historical significance.

properties.Name: Craigflower School
properties.Description: Craigflower School, established on March 5th, 1855, operated for 56 years with a total of 19 different teachers during its tenure. The school's bronze bell, salvaged from the steamer Major Tompkins wrecked off Macaulay Point, became a notable feature. Throughout its history, the schoolhouse doubled as a community hall and church, hosting monthly services. Designated a provincial heritage site in 1974, Craigflower School stands as the oldest standing schoolhouse in Western Canada.

properties.Name: Selkirk Trestle
properties.Description: Originally built as a railway bridge to facilitate the unloading of logs from Vancouver Island's logging industry, the Selkirk Trestle enabled logs to be pushed off trains directly into the Gorge. Tugboats then transported the logs to the nearby pulp mill. Today, it serves as a segment of the Galloping Goose Trail, popular for cycling commuters and recreational runners and walkers of all speeds. Constructed from fir and hemlock, this 300-meter-long trestle includes a movable middle section that can be raised to allow tall ships to pass underneath.

properties.Name: Nature House
properties.Description: Esquimalt Gorge Park is home to the Gorge Waterway Nature House, established through collaboration among local Non-Governmental Organizations like the World Fisheries Trust, the Township of Esquimalt, and sponsorship from the Victoria Foundation. Officially opened on World Oceans Day (June 8) in 2008, the Nature House provides an engaging educational experience centred on the local ecology, with a particular focus on the Gorge Waterway and its surrounding areas.

properties.Name: Thetis Cove Canal
properties.Description: Continued septic tank contamination frequently rendered the Gorge unsafe for swimming. In 1942, John Day proposed two plans to address these issues. One involved constructing a permanent dam at the Gorge's narrowest point and creating a canal from Portage Inlet to Thetis Cove. Alternatively, he suggested filling the waterway between the Craigflower Bridge and the Gorge Bridge to expand land for new buildings and homes. Day believed that protecting the inlet from harbour contamination would allow water from the Colquitz and Deadman’s Rivers to purify it. He argued that pollution stemmed not only from septic tanks around the Gorge but also significantly from industrial and commercial activities in and around Victoria's harbour. This proposal was envisioned as part of a postwar rehabilitation plan, which also included establishing a park at Portage Inlet featuring picnic grounds, a public beach, and a boat landing—necessitated by wartime gasoline and rubber rationing efforts.

properties.Name: Wrecked cars
properties.Description: On August 28, 2015, a barge carrying wrecked cars tipped into the Gorge Waterway at the end of Jutland Road, causing approximately 20 vehicles to fall into the water. Prior to being loaded onto the barge, all car bodies were drained of fluids according to the company’s standard procedure. However, oil leaked and had to be contained by boons. The responsibility for retrieving the cars from the bottom of the Gorge fell to Schnitzer Steel (now called Radium Recycling) and Seaspan.

properties.Name: BC Hydro Transmission Cables
properties.Description: BC Hydro’s project to replace the transmission cables located under the Gorge Waterway aims to address the critical need to replace a 2.7-kilometre underground transmission cable installed in 1980, which has suffered corrosion. Approximately 0.4 kilometres of this cable lies beneath the Gorge Waterway and spans city streets from the Horsey Substation on Summit Avenue in Victoria to the Esquimalt Substation near Devonshire Road in Esquimalt. This cable plays a crucial role in supplying electricity to Greater Victoria. The objective is to upgrade to the latest transmission cable technology, ensuring long-term reliability and safety of the electricity supply. The replacement involves transitioning from a direct-buried, oil-filled cable to an oil-free cable installed within a duct bank. Once the new cable is operational, the existing underground cable will be decommissioned, removed, and recycled.

properties.Name: HandyDART Salmon-Safe Certification
properties.Description: BC Transit’s HandyDART Centre project facilities, including an administration building and maintenance bay, and planned amenities like a bus wash and parking, are to be located in View Royal. The project aims to support the growth of HandyDART services and expand the conventional bus system in Victoria.

properties.Name: Cadborosaurus
properties.Description: Cadborosaurus, commonly referred to as Caddy, is a legendary sea serpent named after Cadboro Bay in Victoria, BC. The creature is known as hiyitl'iik to the Manhousat people of Sidney Inlet, t'chain-ko to the Sechelt indigenous nations, and numkse lee kwala to the Comox band of Vancouver Island; it has captured imaginations with its mysterious sightings along the Pacific Coast.

properties.Name: Craigflower Bridge Olympia Oyster Relocation
properties.Description: In 2014, the World Fisheries Trust collaborated with the Capital Regional District of Victoria (CRD) on a project to safeguard Olympia Oysters impacted by the Craigflower Bridge Replacement Project. These oysters were relocated from the bridge site to two designated oyster shell reefs located at Christie Point and Esquimalt Gorge Park.

properties.Name: Reefballs
properties.Description: In 2017, three 350-pound hollow concrete artificial reefs (reefballs) were introduced into the Gorge, featuring large holes designed to facilitate water flow and promote oyster settlement, offering them a habitat above muddy substrates.
properties.KeyWords: native species; Olympia Oysters; restoration; revitalization; waterway

properties.Name: Victoria Harbour Bird Sanctuary
properties.Description: Victoria's Migratory Bird Sanctuary, established in 1923, is one of Canada's oldest and most significant bird sanctuaries. This sanctuary provides crucial habitat for a wide variety of migratory bird species, offering them a safe haven during their seasonal migrations. The sanctuary is home to a diverse array of bird species, including waterfowl, shorebirds, and songbirds. It plays a vital role in the conservation of these species by protecting important breeding, feeding, and resting areas.

properties.Name: Gorge Creek
properties.KeyWords: conservation; pollution; public access; revitalization; watershed

properties.Name: Gorge Park Upper Settling Pond
properties.Description: The upper settling pond is a key feature of restoring Gorge Creek. Approximately 1/3 of the run-off from the Township of Esquimalt comes through this culvert, bringing with it many pollutants from roads and ditches. Most of the flow is diverted into the pond where it slows for sediment to settle out. Cattails, sedges, and rushes in and around the pond help to filter contaminants.
properties.KeyWords: contamination; public park; restoration; revitalization; watershed

properties.Name: Gorge Park Upper Bridge
properties.Description: The overflow pipe that leads across the park peninsula to the Gorge can be found at the Upper Bridge. The entire creek flow used to be directed through the pipe, and is still operational during floods. Additionally, the large rocks along the stream bank help slow the water and provide niche habitats for small organisms that help treat the water. There is less tidal exchange this far up the creek, and the green algae seen here (Enteromorpha) is one that indicates greater freshwater influence.
properties.KeyWords: bridge; public park; restoration; revitalization; watershed

properties.Name: Gorge Creek Channel
properties.Description: This creek was restored and the high banks visible across the creek were created when soil was dredged from the lower creek during restoration.

properties.Name: Gorge Park Lower Settling Pond
properties.Description: This deep pool is designed to allow silt with heavy metals and other pollutants to settle out of the water before flowing into the Gorge. Water birds including mallards, widgeons, and herons often forage along these shores. Tree species which have been planted include Red Osier Dogwood, Pacific Ninebark, Nootka Rose, Douglas-fir, and Broadleaf Maples. These trees are native stream-side vegetation and were planted as a part of the restoration project.
properties.KeyWords: pollution; public park; restoration; revitalization; watershed

properties.Name: Gorge Park Lower Bridge
properties.Description: This bridge is where a weir once controlled a swimming pool. Today, a salt marsh has been constructed on the site of the former pool and beach volleyball courts.
properties.KeyWords: bridge; public park; restoration; revitalization; watershed

properties.Name: Forshaw Road Beach
properties.Description: Includes a ramp suitable for a canoe or a kayak launched

properties.Name: Harbour Seals
properties.Description: The harbour seal is British Columbia’s only native true seal. Averaging 5.5 to 6.2 ft. in length and 286 to 375 lbs., these seals live up to 30 years. They inhabit intertidal areas, using vocalizations to communicate. Their diet shifts seasonally, focusing on salmon in summer and autumn. Conservation efforts have increased their population from 10,000 in 1970 to 105,000 today.

properties.Name: Eelgrass
properties.Description: Eelgrass is a keystone species which grows in shallow saltwater areas.  Microorganisms such as algae and bacteria grow on the surface of the eelgrass leaves, which provides food for many marine organisms. This forms the base of a diverse community which depends on the eelgrass meadow for food and shelter.
properties.KeyWords: conservation; estuary; fish; native species; salmon

properties.Name: Cuthbert Holmes Park Trail Relocation and Colquitz River Improvements
properties.Description: In 2020 and 2021 Cuthbert Holmes Park saw significant improvements including trail relocation to prevent flooding, stormwater treatment, and habitat enhancement. The park's restoration involved using woody debris to provide habitat and reduce erosion, establishing new ponds and wetlands, creating side channels in the river estuary, and removing invasive English hawthorn. In 2022, additional side channels were added to provide habitat for juvenile salmon and other wildlife.
properties.KeyWords: colquitz creek; invasive species; public access; revitalization; watershed

properties.Name: Stumps with Purpose
properties.Description: Includes the placement of logs, stumps, woody debris, plants and boulders along the slops to slow water drainage coming off the highway and support habitat diversity.

properties.Name: New Ponds and Wetlands
properties.Description: Establishment of new ponds and wetland habitats serves to capture excess water run-off from highway and residential properties to allow for increased freshwater habitat for local wildlife.
properties.KeyWords: colquitz creek; conservation; restoration; revitalization; watershed

properties.Name: Estuary Fingers
properties.Description: New side channels were created to diversity and increase the habitat in the estuary.
properties.KeyWords: animals; colquitz creek; conservation; restoration; revitalization; watershed

properties.Name: Riparian Restroration
properties.KeyWords: animals; colquitz creek; conservation; restoration; revitalization; watershed

properties.Name: Invasive Species Removal and Planting
properties.KeyWords: colquitz creek; conservation; invasive species; restoration; watershed

properties.Name: Wetland and Habitat Protection
properties.KeyWords: animals; colquitz creek; conservation; revitalization; watershed

properties.Name: Sherwood Park Restoration Site
properties.Description: Sherwood Forest is the woodland East of the Nature House that hosts many restoration projects to support wildlife and forest health. For more information go to : https://www.gorge.ca/projects/sherwood-forest

properties.Name: Indigenous Nature Interpreter Stewardship Site
properties.Description: The Indigenous Nature Interpreter (INI) Stewardship Site is designed as a place for the Esquimalt and Songhees Nations to gather, engage with, and learn about culturally significant plants.

properties.Name: Gorge Creek Salt Marsh Restoration
properties.Description: The Gorge Creek salt marsh is a rare and ecologically rich brackish ecosystem that GWAS is working to restore and protect.

properties.Name: Pollinator Meadow Restoration
properties.Description: The Pollinator Meadow boosts insect biodiversity by attracting native species to Esquimalt Gorge Park.

properties.Name: Eelgrass Survey
properties.Description: Eelgrass is an important foundational species that supports much of the Gorge estuarine ecosystem. It creates habitat for salmon, herring, feeder fish, crustaceans, and many other species. The leaves shed and provide food for decomposers. These creatures support predators like birds. GWAS' eelgrass survey complements other, more in-depth surveys done in the Gorge less frequently. GWAS aim to fill in the gaps from year to year to monitor for big changes. Teams visit 13 sites along the Gorge and estimate density and cover while looking for spots where algae or pollution may be causing damage.

properties.Name: European Green Crab Monitoring
properties.Description: Since 2022, GWAS has participated in the Department of Fisheries and Oceans’ European Green Crab Monitoring Project. European green crabs are a destructive invasive species that removes eelgrass very efficiently, destroying habitat for everything else in the Gorge. Unfortunately, teams caught adult European green crabs in the Gorge for the first time in August 2024 through the monitoring program. GWAS is working with the Department of Fisheries and Oceans and Peninsula Streams Society to remove as many as possible before the problem worsens. To prevent the spread of European Green Crabs, make sure to clean, drain, and dry off any watercraft according to BC Invasives.
